div.p: S. Pl.
Regarding Mr. Peter Martyr, although grieving is of no use, yet somehow the grief itself is pleasant.
Alas for me! Indeed, he was worthy, with that greatness of intellect, that multitude of letters, that piety, those manners, that life, that he should never be taken from life.
But I had already predicted this would happen, as soon as I heard that a man of his age had turned his mind to marriage.
May God, the best and greatest, kindly look upon His church, and raise up others for him who has passed away.
You are few, my father, you are few, upon whom the whole matter now rests; for I have always counted you among the foremost.
Oh, would that there always be some to whom you can entrust this torch! But I will let that be.
Your Hercules of Tübingen, the fabricator of monsters, not the conqueror, now triumphs idly.
In that whole kingdom of his, the Ubiquitarian, with such vast spaces and regions, I wonder if he can stand.

If he wishes to plot anything against a dead man, and his writings can be brought to us, unless one of you wishes to forestall me, I consider it my duty, as far as my affairs allow, to respond to him; if nothing else, at least so it can be understood that England and Switzerland agree against these Ubiquitarians.
The death of the Guise Pharaoh, which we accept today as certain and confirmed, believe me, has struck my innermost soul and heart.
It was so sudden, so opportune, so fortunate, it surpassed all our hope and expectation.

What now do we think is the spirit of our brothers; whom that beast had already surrounded with a siege, and whom he had almost devoured with bloody jaws in hope and thought? Blessed be the name of the Lord.
Châtillon now attacks the fortress of Canossa, and grows daily; and there is good hope that the adversaries will come to our terms, and everything will be as we wish.
Our queen gathers soldiers from Germany, and pays them, and spares no expense.
At this time we are holding a convention of the whole kingdom, and we are discussing religion with favorable minds, and the republic, and the sinews of war, that is, money.
From Scotland, all is reported well.
The queen almost alone retains the Guise obstinacy of mind and her mass, against the will of all.
Our queen suffered from smallpox last autumn, with considerable danger.
Impatient of heat and weariness, she almost destroyed herself. But we give thanks to God, who freed her from danger and us from fear.
What those little fathers of yours in Trento and the hydropic pope are planning, we hear nothing.
Perhaps the Holy Spirit does not wish to be present, or cannot speak.
Whatever it is, in such a convention, with such expectation, it is surprising that nothing is being done.
After the intemperance of last summer and this winter, and several days of spasms and catarrhs, I am now finally beginning to recover.
I do not doubt that you will take care that the writings of Mr. Peter Martyr do not perish: they cost him much while he lived, and they are worthy, as you know, to be held in high regard.
Farewell, most distinguished man, and most esteemed brother and lord in Christ.

Greet that excellent woman, your wife, your sons, daughters-in-law, Mr. Gwalther, Mr. Simler, Mr. Lavater, Mr. Zwingli, Mr. Wick, Mr. Wolf, Mr. Haller, Mr. Gessner, Mr. Frisius in my name. May the Lord keep you safe and sound for us for a long time! March 5, 1563.
Your brother in Christ and most devoted to your name, John Jewel.
